w:r.w:t: This information is provided to Members of Parliament in support of their parliamentary duties and is not intended to address the specific circumstances of any particular individual. It should not be relied upon as being up to date; the law or policies may have changed since it was last updated; and it should not be relied upon as legal or professional advice or as a substitute for it. A suitably qualified professional should be consulted if specific advice or information is required.
This information is provided subject to
which are available online or may be provided on request in hard copy. Authors are available to discuss the content of this briefing with Members and their staff, but not with the general public.

(as part of the national accounts) and
The contribution of any industry to the

economy is best measured by its gross value added (GVA). GVA only considers the actual ‘added value’ of the industry, and excludes intermediate-industry effects. For example, it would be inconsistent to allocate to the
industry the value of output of the raw materials it uses. It is more correct to allocate the value of, say, wood production to the lumber industry, and only apportion to the
’ to the raw material (i.e. wood) consumed.
economic output has been in steady decline for many decades. In 1977, it accounted for 27
The chart at the top of the following page shows that as manufacturing’s contribution to economic output has trended lower
the service sector’s share has continued to rise from 56.7% in 1987 to 76.2% in 2007.
As can be seen in the chart below, manufacturing output growth has long underperformed that of the economy as a whole, largely due to
growth rate of manufacturing has been 0.8%, well below that of services (2.5%) and the economy (2.3%).
The current recession has also hit manufacturing

he number of people working in manufacturing has fallen
sharply over the past 30 years, from 6.9 million in 1978 to 2.9 million in 2008. Th

2009 showing employment in manufacturing of 2.7 million.

As a result of the sharp downturn in manufacturing production during the recession, the number of people made redundant has risen sharply to 67,000 in Q1 2009 from 29,000 a year ago, a 129% increase.

Productivity growth in the manufacturing sector has historically been stronger than in
other sectors of the economy due to its reliance on machinery and equipment, which
productivity due to the nature of many jobs within it.
For example, there is likely not much that can be done to greatly improve efficiency in hairdressing.

It is noticeable though that as output across the whole economy began to decline last year, so too did productivity growth. This is likely because “employers either chose or had to hold on to workers while output declined in 2008.”
After decreasing at the beginning of the decade, the amount of business investment in the manufacturing sector has remained broadly stable in nominal terms, averaging around £15 billio
n a year. However, in real (inflation-adjusted) terms there has been a gradual decline

However, total manufacturing output also depends on domestic demand.

Notes: The sterling effective exchange rate index is a measure of the overall change in the trade-weighted exchange value of sterling, calculated by weighting together bilateral exchange rates. It is designed to measure changes in the price competitiveness of traded goods and services and so the weights reflect trade flows in manufactured goods and services.
does not show a consistent relationship
between exchange rates and manufacturing production, thereby
when attempting to explain changes in manufacturing production.

In 2002 the Government set out its
– allowing businesses to plan for the long-term;
– supporting investment in capital equipment and processes, leading edge technology, skills development, and Research and Development;
’s strong science base to create innovative, high value products;
– helping companies to raise productivity through continuous improvement and lean manufacturing techniques;
– supporting the development of a skilled and flexible manufacturing workforce;
– providing effective transport and communications networks;
– providing the supportive business environment that manufacturing needs to compete globally.
A review of the Strategy conducted in 2004 reiterated the importance of the
in order to “help build a successful, knowledge-intensive, highly-skilled manufacturing sector”.
the Government expanded the role of the Manufacturing Advisory Service (see below)
for Manufacturing, and established the Technology Strategy Board to invest in new technologies and innovations for the benefit of business
to such an R&D intensive sector.
In September 2008, the Government published a

Our vision is for a globally competitive manufacturing sector that leads the world in capturing higher value components of the global value chain, whilst consolidating areas of existing comparative advantage, including activities within high technology manufacturing.
believes are driving change in global manufacturing:
The increasing prevalence and complexity of global value chains
underpinned by developments in information and communication technology, and consequent fragmentation of processes, encouraging specialisation
The accelerated pace of technology exploitation
as the pace and demand for change implementation has increased
The growing importance of investment in intangibles
such as design, branding and R&D
The increased recognition that investment in People and Skills
is among the most important for companies to make
The move to a low carbon economy
as the response to climate change creates both new challenges and opportunities for manufacturing firms
In response, the report says the Government has reviewed and strengthened its strategy to help manufactures
Economic and Business Minister, Ian Pearson,
[…] The manufacturing strategy launched in September is providing £150 million of support for
manufacturing, helping manufacturers to: seize the opportunities of the low carbon economy; significantly increase apprenticeships; and take advantage of new markets in the global economy. […]
In April 2009, the Government set out its “Strategic vision for
’s recovery”, which included information concerning the manufacturing sector, in a document titled
A press release accompanying the release
A written answer from the then Economic and Business Minister, Ian Pearson, summarised the report’s

[…] In April [2009], the Government published "New Industry, New Jobs", which identifies key areas where Government action can speed recovery through investing in growth and building manufacturing and services essential to ensure business can compete successfully in future markets.

It is funded by the nine
and by the Devolved Administrations in
The MAS website recommends that potential users of the service get in touch

The nine English Regional Centres are the recommended first point of contact for users of MAS services. MAS advisers based in the Regional Centres are able to help manufacturers by providing information, advice and follow up support on all manufacturing related issues. Scottish companies should contact Scottish Enterprise for assistance.
Each Regional Centre’s team of experience
support tailored to the needs of individual businesses. They can guide you through changes that will improve the performance of your manufacturing business by producing real results.
additional information on the type of assistance offered

The national network of MAS advisers are focused on delivering results that positively impact on the business’s bottom line; such as reduction in stock levels and wastage rates, removing the need for investment in new machinery through improved space utilisation and improving productivity output through implementation of lean techniques.
positive impact on the manufacturing sector:
Since its inception in 2002, the gross impact from MAS services amounts to £774
million, MAS has dealt with over 150,000 technical enquiries from manufacturers, carried out over 28,000 free on-site diagnostic reviews and more than 9,800 in-depth consultancy projects.
